newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Germany lends Ivory Coast rubber firm 8 mln marks.
newsitem.headline: Germany lends Ivory Coast rubber firm 8 mln marks.

text.p: German development body Deutsche Ivestitions und Entwicklungsgesellschaft (DEG) has given Ivorian rubber firm SOGB an eight million mark loan to promote smallholder plantations, the German embassy in Abidjan said on Wednesday.
It said in a statement that SOGB (Societe de Caoutchouc de Grand Bereby) would repay the loan at 0.75 percent interest over 21 years, with a 10-year grace period.
SOGB, one of Ivory Coast's main rubber producers, has 13,500 hectares of rubber in southwest Ivory Coast. Annual output is about 30,000 tonnes, some 40 percent of national production.
It has a rubber processing plant which could handle output from adjacent smallholder plantations.
The statement said it would cost a total of 13 million marks to finance the project, which would benefit about 400 smallholders.
Smallholders would raise the equivalent of three million marks and SOGB would contribute two million, it added.
SOGB was privatised in 1994 and is majority-owned by Bereby Finance (BEFIN).

Industry sources say BEFIN's main shareholders are Ivorian businessman Fulgence Koffy and Luxembourg firm Socfinal, part of Belgium's Societe Financiere des Caoutchoucs. DEG has an 11 percent stake in the company.
The loan deal was signed on Tuesday.
